<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate how the surrounding temperature affects the rate at which water cools.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 576, 137]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 148, 821, 338]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 144, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 387, 180, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 387, 589, 406]]<|/det|>
• Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 418, 672, 437]]<|/det|>
• Record the temperature \(\theta_{1}\) of the water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{1} =\)  .......................................  ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 480, 185, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 480, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
• Pour hot water into the boiling tube until it is about half full. Gently place the thermometer into the boiling tube. Place the boiling tube into the beaker of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 527, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
• Record, in the **first row** of Table 1.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the boiling tube and immediately start the stopclock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 574, 920, 607]]<|/det|>
• Record, in the table, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the boiling tube at times \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\). Use the first and second columns.  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 619, 144, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 619, 180, 637]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 619, 628, 637]]<|/det|>
• Carefully empty the boiling tube and the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 650, 794, 668]]<|/det|>
• Pour \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water and \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water **into the beaker**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 681, 722, 700]]<|/det|>
• Record the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the warm water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 712, 918, 731]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{2} =\)  ................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 744, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the steps in **(a)(ii)**, recording the temperature \(\theta\) of the water in the boiling tube in the third column of the table.  [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 863, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating how the material of a spring affects its behaviour when stretched.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 539, 122]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 134, 546, 152]]<|/det|>
wires of different thickness, length and material

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 149, 702, 168]]<|/det|>
a set of \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses and a set of \(100\mathrm{g}\) masses, both with hangers

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 532, 183]]<|/det|>
a wooden rod approximately 1 cm in diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 181, 463, 199]]<|/det|>
other standard laboratory equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 211, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which would enable you to test the stretch of springs made from different materials. You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 388, 275]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 288, 141, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 288, 665, 306]]<|/det|>
instructions for making a spring from the wire that is provided,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 134, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 369, 339]]<|/det|>
what you would measure,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 138, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 514, 370]]<|/det|>
instructions for carrying out the experiment,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 383, 136, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 798, 400]]<|/det|>
the variables you would keep the same to ensure the comparison is a fair test,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 136, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 720, 432]]<|/det|>
any precaution which should be taken or difficulty which might occur,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 138, 464]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 445, 455, 463]]<|/det|>
how you would present your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 476, 576, 494]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
